name: Nico Ditch Earthwork (pre-Norman, 5th–11th century)
description: A 6-mile (9.7km) linear earthwork running from Ashton-under-Lyne to Stretford, passing through Denton, Reddish, Gorton, Levenshulme, Burnage, Rusholme, Platt Fields, Withington, and Chorlton-cum-Hardy. 4-5 yards wide, up to 5 feet deep. U-shaped profile suggests a boundary marker rather than military defence. Possibly a Mercian-Northumbrian boundary. Still visible in sections.
notes:
Scheduled Monument #1015132
UMAU excavations 1990-1997

Course: Ashton-under-Lyne → Denton → Reddish → Gorton → Levenshulme → Burnage → Rusholme → Platt Fields → Withington → Chorlton-cum-Hardy → Stretford

Dimensions: 4-5 yards wide, up to 5 feet deep, U-shaped profile

Still visible: 300m stretch at Denton Golf Course, traces in Platt Fields Park

The course is well-documented and could be digitised as a polyline vector feature.
Scheduled monument polygon data available from Historic England GIS downloads.

Provides important context as a pre-existing territorial boundary that would have been a known feature in the 1100-1200 period.
